filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of digital editions of three posthumous copies of America a Prophecy. Copies N and Q were printed by Catherine Blake, c. 1829, and are in the Auckland Public Library and Princeton University Library respectively. Copy P, in the Fitzwilliam Museum, was printed c. 1832 by Frederick Tatham, one of a group of young artists who befriended Blake at the end of his life, calling him the “Interpreter” and themselves the “Ancients.” Tatham cared for Catherine Blake after Blake died in August 1827 and obtained all of Blake’s effects, including the copperplates of Blake's illuminated books, after Catherine died in October 1831. The posthumous copies join America Copies A, B, E, F, M, and O, already in the Archive, and Jerusalem Copy I, a posthumous copy printed by Tatham c. 1832.
Posthumous copies of illuminated books (of Songs, America, Europe, and Jerusalem) are part of Blake's reception history in the nineteenth century. They are also important bibliographically because they accurately reveal the copperplate designs and texts, usually more so than lifetime impressions, which were often printed without plate borders and finished in watercolors, with texts touched up and even altered in pen and ink.
America a Prophecy, dated 1793, was the first of Blake's "Continental Prophecies," followed by Europe a Prophecy in 1794, executed in the same style and size but usually colored, and, in 1795, "Africa" and "Asia," two sections making up The Song of Los. Fine and important examples of all three books are in the Archive.
Blake described America as folio in the 1793 Prospectus and, along with Europe, in his 1818 letter to Dawson Turner. All lifetime copies were folio in size—approximately 37 x 27 cm., which are quarters of Imperial sheets—except America Copy O and Europe Copy K, the last copies that Blake printed, in 1821 for John Linnell, which are quarto in size, at 30 x 24 cm. Catherine Blake appears to have used these late copies as her model, printing America Copy Q and Europe Copy L as matching quartos, at 29.5 x 22.1 cm., on Ruse and Turner laid paper dated 1812. She printed America Copy N and Europe Copy I as matching quartos, at 32.6 x 23.6 cm., on T. Stains wove paper dated 1813. Tatham also paired the two books, printing America Copy P with Europe Copy M as quartos, at 28 x 22.8 cm., on J. Whatman 1832 wove paper.
America comprises eighteen major text and design plates and a small plate (e) bearing the word "Preludium" and printed above the design on Plate 3. Ten of the fourteen lifetime extant copies of America were printed in 1793 on both sides of leaves in bluish and greenish black inks and left uncolored. The last five lines of Plate 4 were masked and did not print, and Plate 13 was printed in its first of two states. She and Tatham printed Plate 4 unmasked, Plates 11 and 13 in their second (final) states, and did not print Plate e. They both printed on one side of the leaf and left the impressions uncolored, but the similarities end there.
Catherine Blake’s impressions are closer in appearance and feel to Blake’s impressions than Tatham’s. She printed in black intaglio ink on dampened paper, resulting in reticulated surfaces and designs shrinking slightly smaller than the plates upon drying. Moreover, she touched up impressions in light washes and numbered them in the top right corner. These features are characteristic of Blake’s practice and differentiate her books from Jerusalem Copies H, I, and J; America Copy P; Europe Copy M; Songs Copies a, b, c, d, e, g, h, i, j, and p, and loose impressions; and Innocence Copy T—that is, from all the books printed on J. Whatman 1831 and 1832 papers by Tatham. He printed on dry paper in relief ink, usually sepia (a brownish red), a hue never used by Blake, and occasionally black, which transferred without reticulating. He did not touch up impressions or number them. Catherine Blake no doubt knew how Blake printed illuminated books from having assisted him in their production.
America Copy Q, though initially uncolored, is now colored because Walter T. Spencer, who acquired it and Europe Copy L between 1913 and 1918, had them colored before selling them as Blake’s printing and coloring. America Copy Q’s coloring was modeled on William Muir’s 1887 lithographic facsimile of America Copy A and went undetected as posthumous until it was exhibited in Philadelphia in 1939. The status of the coloring was confirmed by Geoffrey Keynes and Edwin Wolf in their 1953 Census. They also confirmed that Europe Copy L was posthumously colored, but they did not report posthumous printing for either book. That possibility was first suggested by G. E. Bentley, Jr., in his 1977 Blake Books and, for Europe Copy L, confirmed by Robert N. Essick in his 1985 catalogue of the Huntington collection. The identity of Catherine Blake as printer of America Copy Q as well as Europe Copy L is demonstrated in Joseph Viscomi’s “Posthumous Blake: The Roles of Catherine Blake, C. H. Tatham, and Frederick Tatham in Blake’s Afterlife” (Blake/An Illustrated Quarterly, vol. 53. no. 3, Fall 2019).
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objdescid.origination: William Blake author, inventor, delineator, etcher
Catherine Blake printer. This copy of *America* was printed after Blake's death by his wife Catherine c. 1829.
Catherine Blake colorist. Blake's wife Catherine added light gray washes to many of the Objects in this copy. She also darkened some printed areas with black washes.

objinfo.numberobj: 18In Copies C-I, K, L, and R, the word "Preludium" (not "PRELUDIUM," pace Bentley page 91 and Erdman page 802) is printed above Bentley Plate 3 from a small, separate copperplate, Plate e, 2.4 x 8.0 cm. In Copies A, B, and N-Q, the word "Preludium" is omitted. In Copy M, "PRELUDIUM" (all capitals) is written by hand. In this copy Object 10 is in the second of two states, with additional white line work in the lower left margin just above the bottom edge of the plate. The first state is found only in Copy L. Object 13 is in the second (final) state, with one tail on the snake, lower left.
objinfo.objsize: ranging between 23.8 x 17.4 cm. and 23.1 x 16.3 cm.
objinfo.medium: Relief etching, with extensive white-line etching on Objects 1, 8, 10, 12, and 15, and with light gray and/or black washes added to many Objects. Most plates bear at least touches of white-line etching/engraving.
objinfo.watermark: R & T and RUSE & TURNERS / 1812The R & T watermark appears on Objects 1, 2, 7, 10, 11, 13, 16, and 17. The dated watermark appears on Objects 3-6, 8, 9, 12, 14, 15, and 18.
objinfo.pennednumbers: 1-18The numbers appear upper right above each Object. These numbers were probably written by Catherine Blake.
objinfo.binding: Bound in maroon embossed cloth with *Europe* Copy I.

provenance.name: Auckland Public Library
provenance.note: Acquired by the artist James Ferguson (1791-1871) from Catherine Blake, probably in 1829, along with *Europe* Copy I and *Visions of the Daughters of Albion* Copy N; acquired c. 1871 with *Europe* Copy I by George Grey (1799-1882) "at the sale of the effects of a deceased artist" (according to a pencil note by Grey written in *America* Copy N, bound with Copy I of *Europe*); the volume given or bequeathed by Grey to the Auckland Public Library in 1882.

desc.objtitle:
America a Prophecy,
Object 1 (Bentley 1, Erdman i, Keynes i)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design embodies the destructiveness of warfare. In the middle distance is a stone wall with, on the right, the fragments of a top carved with classical motifs. A great gap appears to the left, and in this gap sits a giant winged figure. He is nude and muscular, with prominent knees and feet and both arms shackled and chained to the ground or to remnants of the wall on which he squats or sits. His legs are drawn up in an extremely contracted posture, with his knees to his shoulders. His head is lowered and rests on his knees; his face is not pictured. His hair is long and curly. The contracted posture and lowered head suggest despair. He may be Albion's Angel, the representative of the establishment forces, or Orc, the personification of revolution. To the right is a family group, all nude. A woman, very probably a mother, sits on a fragment of the stone wall. Her hair is long and her face expresses a brooding fear, despair, or simply exhaustion. She holds in her lap a young child, probably male. He faces forward, and his (right?) knee is prominent. Another child, of uncertain gender, leans against the woman's left thigh and hip and hides his or her head below the woman's left arm. This figure's legs are crossed at the ankles. We see this figure from behind. On the ground on the far left is a dismounted cannon. The sky is dominated by dark clouds, perhaps of smoke.

component.illusobjdesc: A giant winged male sits or squats in a gap in a partly-destroyed wall. He is nude and muscular, with prominent knees and feet and both arms shackled and chained to the ground or to the remnants of the wall on which he squats or sits. His legs are drawn up in an extremely contracted posture, with his knees to his shoulders. His head is lowered and rests on his knees; his face is not pictured. His hair is long and curly. The contracted posture and lowered head suggest despair. He may be Albion's Angel, the representative of the establishment forces, or Orc, the personification of revolution.
The giant winged figure is shackled and chained.

Three nude figures, probably a mother and two children, huddle together. The woman sits on a fragment of the stone wall. Her hair is long and her face expresses a brooding fear. She holds in her lap a young child, probably male. He faces forward but perhaps looks up toward the woman. His (right?) knee is prominent. Another child, of uncertain gender, leans against the woman's left thigh and hip and hides his or her head below the woman's left arm. We see this figure from behind.

A nude female, probably the mother of the two children with her, sits on a fragment of the stone wall. Her hair is long and her face expresses a brooding fear, despair, or simply exhaustion. Her legs are crossed and her right hand rests on her right knee. She holds in her lap a young child, probably male.
The woman holds in her lap a nude child, probably male. He faces forward. We see only his face, right upper arm, and prominent (right?) knee.

A nude child of uncertain gender huddles with the woman. We see this figure from behind; his or her head is hidden by the woman's left arm. The figure's legs are crossed at the ankles; the buttocks are prominent. Long hair cascades over the figure's right shoulder.

The middle distance of the design is dominated by a stone wall, partly ruined. The top is decorated with classical motifs, perhaps including the egg and dart motif (upper right) and palmettes on the fragment of the wall on which the woman sits.
The sky is dominated by clouds, perhaps of smoke.
A dismounted cannon lies on the ground.
The fragment of the wall on which the giant winged figure sits looks like a plinth. This effect suggests that the figure is like a statue.
The ground would seem to be covered with rounded (cobble?) stones.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design is framed by a dark, rippling border, perhaps suggesting cloud or water forms. To the left of the imprint hovers a faint shadow. Above the imprint are male corpses stacked like cord wood. We see, on the first level of the stack, the tops of the heads and horizontally-extended arms of two rigid bodies lying prone. The next layer is a single rigid body, lying supine, with his legs extended to the right and his arms at his side. He faces up. His feet are bare. Above him is a gowned woman with long hair, lying on top of him with her left leg drawn up and her right leg extended. She embraces the man around his head with her left arm. Her face, seen in profile, touches the dead or dying man's face below her; she may be kissing him, trying to resuscitate him, or simply mourning over him. Her mouth is partly open. The dark sky above these figures contains a few diagonal lines that may indicate rain or sleet descending from the clouds above. These large clouds bear the title, as though inscribed upon them, and six figures. On the left, a gowned woman with long hair sits with right leg extended before her and her left leg bent back behind her. She faces and hunches over to the left, apparently holding a book or tablet before which stands a gowned child, probably male, with curly hair. His right arm is extended over the book or tablet, and he looks down at it. Behind the woman is another figure, perhaps nude and female, sitting with legs extended and her back leaning against the back of the woman. Although the scale of the figures is uncertain, this may be a child or young girl. Another group of three figures is on the right. An old, bearded man with long hair sits facing to the right. He wears a heavy gown and hunches over a book or tablet on his lap, at which he appears to be looking and perhaps reading. His posture is contracted, in contrast to the figure to the right—a nude female hovering in the air. We see her from behind; her posture is gracefully twisted. Her left arm is raised horizontally, her right arm at 135 degrees. The index finger on her right hand points upward. Her right leg is extended, her left drawn up. Her hair is in a bun. Behind the old man is a nude male, youthful and facing to the right although his body is turned to the left and leans against the back of the old man. His legs are crossed and he points upward and to the left with his right arm, hand, and extended index finger at an angle of 135 degrees. His left arm is at his side. Although these two nude figures are much smaller than the old man, they are probably not children but energetic representations of spiritual states unperceived, or ignored, by the old man. The two large figures with books or tablets have sometimes been identified as a sibyl and a prophet. Alternatively, the male may be a priest.

component.illusobjdesc: The rippling border around the image suggests clouds or water.

The lowest part of the design is formed of male corpses stacked like cord wood. We see, on the first level of the stack, the tops of the heads and horizontally-extended arms of two rigid bodies lying prone. Their hair is long.

A male lies supine on top of the prone corpses. His legs extend to the right and his arms are at his side. He faces up. He is rigid and is probably dead or dying. His feet are bare. He may be holding something in his right hand, possibly the haft of a broken sword.
The supine male just below the gowned woman may be holding something in his right hand, possibly the haft of a broken sword.

Above the supine male is a gowned woman with long hair, lying on top of him with her left leg drawn up and her right leg extended. She embraces the man around the neck with her left arm. Her face, seen in profile, touches the dead or dying man's face below her; she may be kissing him, trying to resuscitate him, or simply mourning over him. Her mouth is open.

Left of the word "a" in the title inscription (line 3), a gowned woman with long hair sits with right leg extended before her and left leg bent back behind her. She faces and hunches over to the left, apparently holding, with her extended left arm and hand, a book or tablet which she may be reading. She has sometimes been identified as a sibyl.
The seated woman holds and appears to read a book or tablet in her lap.
A gowned child with curly hair, probably male, stands before the seated woman. He faces right. His right arm is raised horizontally and extends over the book or tablet held by the woman.

Behind the large seated woman is another figure, probably nude and female, sitting with legs extended and her back leaning against the back of the woman. Although the scale of the figures is uncertain, this may be a child or young girl. She turns her head toward us. Her right arm dangles at her side, and she may be pointing downward.

Right of the word "a" in the title inscription (line 3), an old, bearded man with long hair sits facing to the right. He wears a heavy gown and hunches over a book or tablet on his lap, at which he appears to be looking and perhaps reading. He may be a prophet or priest.
The seated old man holds and appears to read a book or tablet in his lap.

A nude female hovers in the air right of the old man. We see her from behind; her body is gracefully twisted, with her head facing to the left. Her left arm is raised horizontally, her right at 135 degrees. The index finger on her right hand points upward. Her right leg is extended, her left drawn up. Her hair is in a bun.

Behind the old man is a nude male, youthful and facing to the right although his body is turned to the left and leans against the back of the old man. His legs are crossed and he points upward and to the left with his right arm, hand, and extended index finger at an angle of 135 degrees. His left arm is bent and supported against the old man's back, against which he leans. A lock of his (long?) hair drifts to the left.

The dark and stormy sky above the woman lying on the corpses contains cloud outlines and diagonal lines perhaps representing rain or sleet. The angle of the rain or sleet indicates a wind blowing from left to right.
The upper two-thirds of the plate contains cloud outlines. Both the title words and associated figures float seem to float on these clouds or hover before them.

lg.l: AMERICA
a
PROPHECY
LAMBETH
Printed by William Blake in the year 1793,

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although the plate contains considerable text, it appears as though the plate is treated as a single design extending across the top one third, down the left margin, and across the lower margin. A large tree, perhaps an oak, with arching branches dominates the top left of the design. The vegetation right and left of the large trunk may be separate bushes. Below and to the right of its trunk is an earthen bank (possibly covered with grass or moss) to which is shackled a nude, youthful male by both hands and feet. His arms are spread out horizontally on the rock, as if crucified; his legs are also spread apart. His torso and neck are twisted, perhaps in pain; he faces up. His mouth is open; he may be speaking or crying in pain. His hair is curly; he is probably Orc, the spirit of revolution here restrained. To the right are a nude male and female, both standing. The female, with legs spread apart, grasps her head with both hands, as if in mourning or despair. We do not see her face, but her upper torso is twisted to the left—toward the shackled youth. She may be Enitharmon, Orc's mother. Further to the right, the male stands with legs spread apart. His body faces us, but he turns his head to the left and may be looking at the shackled youth. His arms, with elbows bent, are raised over his head, with his hands raised, palms out, and the fingers of both hands spread apart. His hair is spiky or flame-like. His mouth may be slightly open; he may be speaking or crying out in sorrow. This may be Los, Orc's father. Alternatively, the couple has been identified as Adam and Eve, or as the "Dark virgin" and Urthona (another name for Los) mentioned on this plate (lines 12, 2). The roots of the tree descend through the left margin, perhaps taking on anthropomorphic shapes. At the end of the roots, in the far lower left corner of the plate, sits or squats a nude, youthful male in a severely contracted posture. His legs are drawn up, with his head resting on his knees. He faces forward, with a grim expression, and holds his crossed hands over his ankles. His hair is curly or flame-like. This may be another representation of Orc, as the personification of underground forces of revolution now enclosed but with the potential to break out. A reticulated worm, with six loops, fills the lower margin. The loops suggest (although they do not quite form) a spiral.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude, youthful male is shackled to an earthen bank by both hands and feet. We can see a link or two of chains attached to the shackles. His arms and fingers are spread out horizontally on the rock, as if crucified; his legs are also spread apart. His torso and neck are twisted, perhaps in pain; he faces up. His mouth is open; he may be speaking or crying in pain. His hair is curly; he is probably Orc, the spirit of revolution here restrained.
The wrists and ankles of the youth with arms and legs spread bear shackles and a few links of chains.

A nude female, with long hair and legs spread apart, grasps her head with both hands, as if in mourning or despair. We do not see her face, but her upper torso is twisted to the left—toward the shackled youth. She may be Enitharmon, Orc's mother, but she has also been identified as Eve or as the "Dark virgin" named on the plate (line 12).

A nude male stands with legs spread apart. His body faces us, but his head is turned to the left and may be looking at the shackled youth. His arms, with elbows bent, are raised over his head, with his hands raised, palms out, and the fingers of both hands spread apart. His hair is spiky or flame-like. His mouth is slightly open; he may be speaking or crying out in sorrow. This may be Los, Orc's father, but he has also been identified as Urthona (another name for Los, mentioned on this plate) and as Adam.

In the far lower left corner of the plate sits or squats a nude, youthful male in a severely contracted posture. His legs are drawn up, with his head resting on his knees. He faces forward, with a grim expression, and holds his crossed hands over his ankles. His hair is curly or flame-like. This may be another representation of Orc, as the personification of underground forces of revolution now enclosed but with the potential to break out.
A large, reticulated worm fills the lower margin. Its six loops suggest, but do not quite form, a spiral.

A large tree, perhaps an oak, dominates the top left quarter of the plate. Its branches arch over to the right; a few leaves appear on the descending branches far right. Its roots descend down the left margin of the plate; some have anthropomorphic shapes, particularly left of lines 11-16 of the text.
A dark shadow extends along the left side of the tree visible in the upper left corner.
The vegetation right and left of the large trunk of the tree may be separate, leafy plants.
The ground below the shackled figure may be covered with grass or perhaps moss.
The youthful male is shackled to an earthen bank.
Narrow shadows appear below the feet of the standing man and woman.
The contracted figure lower left sits on a mound.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The spaces between lines of text are filled with vegetative motifs, including vines. Some bear leaves, most prominently right of lines 17-18, and some may bear flowers. Vines right of lines 2 and 6 form loops. The vine left of lines 20- 21 forms a small spiral.

component.illusobjdesc: The spaces between lines of text are filled with vegetative motifs, including vines. Some bear leaves, most prominently right of lines 17-18, and some may bear flowers. Vines right of lines 2 and 6 form loops. A vine above the middle of line 16 may suggest the serpent mentioned in that line. The vine left of lines 20- 21 forms a small spiral.

l.note: In Copies C-I, K, L, and R, the word "Preludium" (not "PRELUDIUM," pace Bentley page 91 and Erdman page 802) is printed from a small, separate copperplate, Plate e, 2.4 x 8.0 cm. In Copies A, B, N-Q, the word "Preludium" is omitted. In Copy M, "PRELUDIUM" (all capitals) is written by hand.

lg.l: The shadowy daughter of Urthona stood before red Orc,
When fourteen suns had faintly journey'd o'er his dark abode;
His food she brought in iron baskets, his drink in cups of iron;
Crown'd with a helmet & dark hair the nameless female stood;
A quiver with its burning stores, a bow like that of night.
When pestilence is shot from heaven; no other arms she need:
Invulnerable tho' naked, save where clouds roll round her loins,
Their awful folds in the dark air; silent she stood as night;
For never from her iron tongue could voice or sound arise;
But dumb till that dread day when Orc assay'd his fierce embrace.In copy N, the "c" and "e" in "embrace" at the end of line 11 printed very lightly and are difficult to see.
Dark virgin; said the hairy youth. thy father stern abhorr'd;
Rivets my tenfold chains while still on high my spirit soars;
Sometimes an eagle screaming in the sky, sometimes a lion.
Stalking upon the mountains, & sometimes a whale I lash
The raging fathomless abyss, anon a serpent folding
Around the pillars of Urthona, and round thy dark limbs,
On the Canadian wilds I fold, feeble my spirit folds.
For chaind beneath I rend these caverns; when thou bringest food
I howl my joy: and my red eyes seek to behold thy face
In vain! these clouds roll to & fro, & hide thee from my sight.

objnote.p: Lines 19-23 appear only in Copies A, N-Q. In Copies B-F, H-M, R, and a, these five lines were deleted by being masked during printing; in Copy G, they were erased after printing (Bentley page 94).

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although containing a good deal of text, the plate is treated almost as a full-page design, with pictorial motifs filling the lower third of the plate and continuing up the left margin. In the lower margin, a muscular nude youth with curly, flame- like hair seems to be rising out of the ground. The figure's right knee and foot are prominent; his hands are placed on the ground and his arms, bent sharply at the elbows, seem to be pushing him upward. He looks up and to the right. This is probably Orc. To the left are a good many roots, as though we could see below the surface of the earth. Above these roots is a large plant growing up the left margin. It bears two large leaves and a long branch that terminates in a grain tassel. To the left of the main trunk or stem is a vine-like branch that spirals upward with one loop around the main stem. There are a few small plants and tufts of grass right of the nude male and left and right of the large plant. A dark, uneven border surrounds the illustration and text.

component.illusobjdesc: A muscular nude youth with curly, flame-like hair seems to be rising out of the ground. His right knee and foot are prominent; his hands are placed on the ground and his arms, bent sharply at the elbows, seem to be pushing him upward. He looks up and to the right. This is probably Orc.
The figure appears to be rising from a small depression (possibly a grave?) in a mound of earth, small hill, or side of a cliff.
The surface of the earth is indicated on the right and left by a few small plants with leaves and perhaps grass.

A large plant dominates the left margin of the plate. We see its roots beneath the surface of the earth, two large leaves, and a long branch growing up the left margin that terminates in a grain tassel. To the left of the main trunk or stem is a vine-like branch that spirals upward with one loop around the main stem.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The spaces between lines of text and in the margins are filled with vegetative motifs. Some of these vines bear leaves; large vines left of lines 3-6 and 8-16 include loops. On top of the second of these vines, just above the first word in line 8, is a small seated figure, bending forward and facing to the right with at least one leg extended to the right and one arm possibly reaching toward the foot. Another small figure seems to be hovering above "have" in the same line of text, facing left, one arm raised horizontally and one raised vertically, and legs spread apart. This figure may be holding the vine to the left. A vine growing from the first letter of the last word in line 8 ("go") includes two loops suggestive of a spiral. A bird with extended wings flies at the end of line 16; smaller birds fly above "will" (line 8) and "me" (line 10). The last word line 18 grows into a vine with a leaf and a detached leaf above it; most of this vine turns to the left and underscores the line of text. Loopy vines appear as letter extensions left of lines 19-21.

component.illusobjdesc: A small figure sits on the vine above the first word of line 8 of the text. He or she faces to the right, bending forward with at least one leg extended and one arm possibly reaching toward the foot.
A small figure hovers above "have" in line 8 of the text. He or she faces left, one arm raised horizontally and one vertically, and legs spread apart. The figure may be holding the vine to the left.

The spaces between lines of text and in the margins are filled with vegetative motifs. Some of these vines bear leaves; large vines left of lines 3-6 and 8-16 include loops. A vine growing from the first letter of the last word in line 8 ("go") includes two loops suggestive of a spiral.
A bird with extended wings flies at the end of line 16. Smaller birds fly above "will" (line 8) and "me" (line 10).
The last word of the final line of text grows into a vine with one leaf and a detached leaf above it; most of this vine turns to the left and underlines the last line of text.
Loopy vines appear as letter extensions left of lines 19-21.

lg.l: Silent as despairing love. and strong as jealousy.
The hairy shoulders rend the links, free are the wrists of fire;
Round the terrific loins he siez'd the panting struggling womb;
It joy'd: she put aside her clouds & smiled her first-born smile;
As when a black cloud shews its light'nings to the silent deep.
Soon as she saw the terrible boy then burst the virgin cry.
I know thee, I have found thee, & I will not let thee go;
Thou art the image of God who dwells in darkness of Africa;
And thou art fall'n to give me life in regions of dark death.
On my American plains I feel the struggling afflictions
Endur'd by roots that writhe their arms into the nether deep:
I see a serpent in Canada, who courts me to his love;
In Mexico an Eagle, and a Lion in Peru;
I see a Whale in the South-sea, drinking my soul away.
O what limb rending pains I feel. thy fire & my frost
Mingle in howling pains, in furrows by thy lightnings rent;
This is eternal death; and this the torment long foretold.

The stern Bard ceas'd, asham'd of his own song; enrag'd he swungLines 19-23 appear only in Copies A, N-Q. In Copies F-F, H-M, R, and a, these five lines were deleted by being masked during printing; in Copy G, they were erased after printing (Bentley page 94).
His harp aloft sounding, then dash'd its shining frame against
A ruin'd pillar in glittring fragments; silent he turn'd away,
And wander'd down the vales of Kent in sick & drear la-
-mentings.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The area above the text bearing the heading ("A / PROPHECY," lines 2-3) apparently represents the sky with cloud outlines added in grey wash. Six birds fly on extended wings; three of these seem to be soaring upwards. Upper left, a nude, muscular male also seems to be ascending. He has apparently broken free of the chains that still dangle from his wrists. His right arm is at his side; his left arm is bent back over his left shoulder. His left leg is bent behind him; we see only the left ankle and foot. His hair may be curly. He faces forward, with head tilted up. This may be another representation of Orc or, more generally, humanity freed from its chains by revolution. The words of the heading are integrated into vegetative design motifs, including several vines with leaves, spiraling vines growing from the first and last letters of "PROPHECY" (line 3), and grain stems and tassels growing from the first word of the heading ("A," line 2).

component.illusobjdesc: A nude, muscular male ascends through the sky. He has apparently broken free of the chains that still dangle from his wrists. His right arm is at his side; his left arm is bent back over his left shoulder. His left leg is bent behind him; we see only the left ankle and foot. His hair may be curly. He faces forward with his head tilted up. This may be another representation of Orc or, more generally, humanity freed from its chains by revolution.
Chains dangle from the wrists of the ascending figure.
Cloud outlines have been added in gray wash.
A bird flies on extended wings just left of the first letter of "PROPHECY" in the heading (line 3). Another bird flies above the upper loop of the first letter of the first word ("The") of line 4.

Four birds fly on extended wings: a rising bird above the "C" of "PROPHECY" in line 3, another rising bird below this same letter, a rising bird right of the descender of the final letter of "PROPHECY," and, just above this bird, a smaller bird flying horizontally. All but the last of these birds have forked tails.

The first diagonal of "A" in line 2 grows at its lower end into a vine terminated by either leaves or a flower with a prominent stamen. Descending from the middle of the letter is an intertwined vine with small flowers. The second diagonal of "A" in line 2 grows at its lower end into arching grain stems with tassels.
The first letter of "PROPHECY" in line 3 grows into a spiral vine, upper left. Another vine, with ivy-like leaves and perhaps flowers, is intertwined with the letter.
The third letter of "PROPHECY" in line 3 grows into a spiral vine. The next letter grows, lower left, into a vine with one loop.
The top of "H" in "PROPHECY" (line 3) grows into a vine with one loop. The vine terminates either in some leaves or a flower with a prominent stamen.
The descender of the last letter of "PROPHECY" in line 3 grows into a vine running horizontally below the word. The vine has three loops, suggesting a spiral.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Between lines 8 and 9 of the text, a hovering nude male, perhaps an apocalyptic angel of the last trump, blows into a large trumpet he holds with at least his left hand. We see him from behind; his hair is long and streams to the left, as though blown by a wind. Issuing from the mouth of the trumpet is a great blast of fire that turns upward in the left margin of the plate. Below, and evidently part of the same design, are further flames and smoke, including a line of fire between lines 15 and 17 of the text. In the lower left corner of the plate is a nude family group fleeing from the fires above and behind them. The male (father?) is in the middle; he holds the hand of a young boy on the left. He strides forward with his left leg and looks back at the flames. His hair may be curly. The woman (mother?) strides forward with her right leg, also turns back to the flames, and raises her left arm over her head. The fingers of her left hand are spread apart. The boy on the left strides forward with his left leg, also seems to be looking back, and raises his right arm over his head. All three figures stride over a small mound of earth or hill.

On the right of the family group is a nude woman, perhaps the mother. She strides forward with her right leg, fleeing the flames above and behind her. lg.l: The Guardian Prince of Albion burns in his nightly tent,
Sullen fires across the Atlantic glow to America's shore:
Piercing the souls of warlike men, who rise in silent night.
Washington, Franklin, Paine & Warren, Gates, Hancock & Green;
Meet on the coast glowing with blood from Albions fiery Prince.
Washington spoke; Friends of America look over the Atlantic sea;
A bended bow is lifted in heaven, & a heavy iron chain
Descends link by link from Albions cliffs across the sea to bind
Brothers & sons of America, till our faces pale and yellow;
Heads deprest, voices weak, eyes downcast, hands work-bruis'd,
Feet bleeding on the sultry sands, and the furrows of the whip
Descend to generations that in future times forget.------
sea;
The strong voice ceas'd; for a terrible blast swept over the heaving
The eastern cloud rent; on his cliffs stood Albions wrathful Prince
A dragon form clashing his scales at midnight he arose,
And flam'd red meteors round the land of Albion beneath
His voice, his locks, his awful shoulders, and his glowing eyes,

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although the plate contains considerable text, it would appear that the pictorial image is treated as a full-plate design. At top right, just below line 2, is a winged dragon of a type traditionally called a wyvern. The creature is apparently flying through the air. It faces to the left, with a coiled or spiral tail with one loop on the right. Its skin looks scaly and its face is somewhat dog-like, with a partly opened mouth and large teeth. The top of its head bears a crest. Its front paws look almost like human hands. Below and to the left of its left paw is a jagged line, perhaps representing a bolt of lightning. Further to the left, and descending into the left margin, is an old man. His gown forms a long, snake-like tail behind him, rather like the wyvern's tail. He has a long beard and long hair. His right arm is at his side, but we can see that, with his right hand, he grasps a large book or tablet. His left arm reaches downward and he holds in his left hand a scepter or spear with a fleur-de-lis point. This figure may be Albion's Angel or Urizen (twice referred to in the text) with his book of laws. Below this descending figure is another jagged line, perhaps representing lightning, and several cloud outlines extending to the right margin above and below the last two lines of text. Below these billowing clouds, in the plate's lower margin, is a landscape that includes three figures, probably a family group of father, mother, and child. Lower left is the trunk of a large tree, fallen on the ground to the left. On the right, behind the figure group, is another fallen tree with three limbs near the right margin. The male is the left-most figure in the group, lower right. He is nude and squats or kneels on the ground, with his upper body bent forward. Both arms are raised and bent at the elbows; he grasps his head with both hands. This gesture expresses despair or terror. To the right is a crouching nude figure. The heavy musculature suggests a male, but this may be a female. Her left knee and foot are prominent. She turns her head to the right; we cannot see her face because it is covered by the head of a child of uncertain gender she embraces. This child is standing and is gowned. These two figures seem to be seeking protection in each other's arms.

component.illusobjdesc: Just below line 2 is a winged dragon of a type traditionally called a wyvern. The creature is apparently flying through the air. It faces to the left, with a coiled or spiral tail with one loop on the right. Its skin looks scaly and its face is somewhat dog-like, with a partly opened mouth and large teeth. The top of the head bears a spiky crest. Its front paws look almost like human hands.

An old man descends head-first in the left margin. His gown forms a long, snake-like tail behind him, but his left leg and foot are still visible. He has a long beard and long hair. His right arm is at his side, but we can see that, with his right hand, he grasps a large book or tablet. His left arm reaches downward and he holds in his left hand a scepter or spear with a fleur-de-lis point. In the plate's lower margin is a landscape that includes three figures, possibly a family group of father, mother, and child.

The male (perhaps the father) is the left-most figure in the family group, lower right. He is nude and squats or kneels on the ground, with his upper body bent slightly forward and his face turned partly downward. Both arms are raised and bent at the elbows; he grasps his head with both hands. This gesture expresses despair or terror.

Although the figure's heavy musculature suggests a male, the crouching figure in the family group, lower right, may be the mother. She is nude; her left knee and foot are prominent. She turns her head to the right; we cannot see her face because it is covered by the head of a child of uncertain gender she embraces.
The woman embraces a child of uncertain gender. This child is standing and wears a gown.
A jagged line below and to the left of the dragon's left paw may represent lightning.
A jagged line below the descending old man may represent lightning.
The sky is filled with the outlines of clouds.

The trunk of a large, fallen tree dominates the landscape, lower left. One short branch and at two roots are pictured. Another fallen tree appears behind the figures, lower right, and divides into three branches near the right margin of the design.
Beneath the tree, to the right of the embracing figures, a shadow fills the corner and blends into a dark border.

lg.l: Appear to the Americans upon the cloudy night.
Solemn heave the Atlantic waves between the gloomy nations,
Swelling. belching from its deeps red clouds & raging fires;
Albion is sick. America faints! enrag'd the Zenith grew.
As human blood shooting its veins all round the orbed heaven
Red rose the clouds from the Atlantic in vast wheels of blood
And in the red clouds rose a Wonder o'er the Atlantic sea;
Intense! naked! a Human fire fierce glowing, as the wedge
Of iron heated in the furnace; his terrible limbs were fire
With myriads of cloudy terrors banners dark & towers
Surrounded; heat but not light went thro' the murky atmo-
-sphere

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although containing considerable text, the plate is treated as a full-plate design with six nude figures. Top left is a man hovering horizontally in the air in front of a cloud. His left leg extends back and up behind him; his left arm extends out to the right and he points in that direction with his left index finger. In his right hand he holds large scales (or, more precisely, a pair of balances), perhaps to be associated with the Day of Judgment. This figure may be a personification of Justice. He has long hair and looks up and to the right at the pair of figures to his right. The lower man in this pair seems to be standing, with one leg bent and one extended, on the outline of the cloud. He is bent over, with his face hidden. His hair is curly. With both arms bent at the elbows and extended over his head he carries on his back another nude male. This figure, in an extremely contracted posture, has his arms tied with rope behind his back, both legs drawn up, and his head and upper body bent over so that his head seems to touch his groin or left thigh. Perhaps we are to think that the man holding this figure is about to cast him into the abyss. Further to the right, but still above the text area, is another nude figure with long hair that forms loops, but also hair pulled back into a bun. This coiffure suggests that, in spite of the heavy musculature, this figure may be female. We see her from behind, floating vertically in the air, with legs slightly spread. Her left arm is raised, her right is lowered, but she grasps with both hands a giant sword with flames emanating from its edge and trailing off to the right, as though blown by a wind. The arm position suggests that she may be sheathing the sword, although no sheath is clearly pictured. This figure, perhaps another personification of Justice, looks to the right. Below the text are large tongues of flame, perhaps suggesting hell. Just above or within these fires are two more nude males. The figure on the left hovers horizontally in the air, although he may be falling into the flames below. His hair is curly. His knees are drawn up toward his torso and he grasps the back of his head with both hands and faces down. This gesture suggests despair. To the right is a male falling head-first. His knees are sharply bent and he too seems to grasp his head with both hands. Around him circles a giant snake, with open mouth and a forked tongue. Below the human figure, the snake's tail forms a spiral into which the man may be falling. The skin of the snake is scaly.

Perhaps we are to think that he is about to throw his victim into the abyss below.

A muscular nude male is held over the head of another male. Perhaps we are to think that the man holding this figure is about to cast him into the abyss.

Upper right is another nude figure, with long hair that forms loops, but also hair pulled back into a bun. This coiffure suggests that, in spite of the heavy musculature, this figure may be female. We see her from behind, hovering vertically in the air, with legs slightly spread. Her left arm is raised, her right is lowered, but she grasps with both hands a giant sword with flames emanating from its edge and trailing off to the right, as though blown by a wind. The arm position suggests that she may be sheathing the sword, although no sheath is clearly pictured. This figure, perhaps another personification of Justice, looks to the right.

A muscular, nude male hovers horizontally in the air, although he may be falling into the flames below. His hair is curly. His knees are drawn up toward his torso and he grasps the back of his head with both hands and faces down. This gesture suggests despair.

A muscular, nude male falls head-first. His knees are sharply bent and he seems to grasp his head with both hands— a gesture indicating despair. Around him circles a giant snake, with open mouth and a forked tongue. Below the human figure, the snake's tail forms a spiral into which the man may be falling.
A giant snake with open mouth and forked tongue almost completes a circle around the falling nude male. The snake's tail, into which the man may be falling, forms a spiral. The snake's skin is scaly.
A cloud hovers behind the man holding scales.
The flames emanating from the sword suggest a wind blowing from left to right.

The lower areas of the plate, right and left of the snake and falling man, contain tongues of fire and accompanying smoke on the far right. These may be the fires of hell. They seem to issue from the tail of the serpent, bottom center.

lg.l: Albions Angel stood beside the Stone
of night, and saw
The terror like a comet, or more like the
planet red
That once inclos'd the terrible wandering comets in its sphere.
Then Mars thou wast our center, & the planets three flew round
Thy crimson disk; so e'er the Sun was rent from thy red sphere;
The Spectre glowd his horrid length staining the temple long
With beams of blood; & thus a voice came forth, and shook the
temple

illustration.illusobjdesc: A youthful, muscular, nude male sits on the ground. His legs are bent at the knees, with thighs spread apart (clearly revealing his genitals) and his feet below the center of his body. His arms are behind him, apparently with hands resting on the ground for support (we see only his right hand on the ground). His hair is curly. His body is slightly twisted as he faces up and to the right. He may be in the act of rising from the ground. Behind are clouds. The earth below may be a small hill or mound covered with grass or moss. Below his right foot and on the right are several leaves, perhaps oak or grape leaves. A vine-like plant with leaves and perhaps flowers decorates the right side of the mound and descends into the right margin of the text. On the left is a skull, facing skyward. This motif suggests that the male may be sitting on a grave—perhaps his own, from which he is rising. Far left are a few tufts of grass and another vine dangling down the left margin of the text; it bears large leaves (perhaps grape).

lg.l: The morning comes, the night decays, the watchmen leave
their stations;
The grave is burst, the spices shed, the linen wrapped up;
The bones of death, the cov'ring clay, the sinews shrunk & dry'd.
Reviving shake. inspiring move, breathing! awakening!
Spring like redeemed captives when their bonds & bars are burst;
Let the slave grinding at the mill, run out into the field;
Let him look up into the heavens & laugh in the bright air;
Let the inchained soul shut up in darkness and in sighing,
Whose face has never seen a smile in thirty weary years;
Rise and look out, his chains are loose, his dungeon doors are open.
And let his wife and children return from the opressors scourge;
They look behind at every step & believe it is a dream.
Singing, The Sun has left his blackness, & has found a fresher morning
And the fair Moon rejoices in the clear & cloudless night;
For Empire is no more, and now the Lion & Wolf shall cease.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although the plate contains seven lines of text, the pictorial image is treated as a full-plate design. The landscape below the text includes, on the left, a large tree, perhaps a birch or willow, growing up the left margin. Its long, slender branches and leaves (or perhaps catkins) arch over the text. Two birds with long, forked tails are perched on the branches of the tree (the remnants of a third bird, etched on the plate, appear to the right of the lower perching bird). Three birds fly in the sky, one upper left among the branches; two much smaller birds fly above "voice" and "Then" in the first line of text. A winged insect, perhaps a moth or butterfly, flies left of the upper perching bird. The landscape below includes grass and two large leaves. The leaf on the left, near the tree, has a vine-like stem; this may be a grape vine. The leaf in the lower right corner might be either a grape or oak leaf. Lying on the grass is a ram, facing right, apparently asleep. A young boy or male child rests his arms and head on the ram's back; his feet (or at least one foot) can be seen right of the ram's head. This boy has curly hair and is probably also sleeping. Below the ram, another youth, but of uncertain gender, is stretched on the grass, perhaps asleep. We see this nude figure from behind. The figure's left leg is extended, the right bent at the knee. The figure's head lies on his or her right arm; we see only the top of the figure's head and long hair. What may be beams of light extend upward to the branches above the text. This gentle, pastoral scene contrasts sharply with the apocalyptic tone of the text on the plate.

lg.l: In thunders ends the voice. Then Albions Angel wrathful burnt
Beside the Stone of Night; and like the Eternal Lions howl
In famine & war. reply'd. Art thou not Orc, who serpent-form'd
Stands at the gate of Enitharmon to devour her children;
Blasphemous Demon. Antichrist. hater of Dignities:
Lover of wild rebellion. and transgresser of Gods Law;
Why dost thou come to Angels eyes in this terrific form?

objnote.p: Object 10 is in the second of two states, with additional white line work in the lower left margin just above the bottom edge of the plate. The first state is found only in Copy L.

Right and left of the child are two plants with large leaves and vine-like tendrils. The plant on the right bears two flowers. Both plants have been identified as poppies. The dark column along the left margin of the plate may be rising smoke or the clouds of an approaching storm.

The right margin of the text is filled with vines, a few bearing leaves. One is looped.

lg.l: Sound! sound! my loud war-trumpets & alarm my Thirteen Angels!
Loud howls the eternal Wolf! the eternal Lion lashes his tail!
America is darkned; and my punishing Demons terrified
Crouch howling before their caverns deep like skins dry'd in the wind.
They cannot smite the wheat, nor quench the fatness of the earth.
They cannot smite with sorrows, nor subdue the plow and spade.
They cannot wall the city, nor moat round the castle of princes.
They cannot bring the stubbed oak to overgrow the hills.
For terrible men stand on the shores, & in their robes I see
Children take shelter from the lightnings, there stands Washington
And Paine and Warren with their foreheads reard toward the east
But clouds obscure my aged sight. A vision from afar!
Sound! sound! my loud war-trumpets & alarm my thirteen Angels:
Ah vision from afar! Ah rebel form that rent the ancient

Heavens! Eternal Viper self-renew'd, rolling in cloudsBlake etched an exclamation mark after "Heavens," but in copy N the vertical stroke was not inked, except for a bottom and top edge, and prints mostly as a blind embossment.
I see thee in thick clouds and darkness on America's shore.
Writhing in pangs of abhorred birth; red flames the crest rebellious
And eyes of death; the harlot womb oft opened in vain
Heaves in enormous circles, now the times are return'd upon thee,
Devourer of thy parent, now thy unutterable torment renews.
Sound! sound! my loud war trumpets & alarm my thirteen Angels.
Ah terrible birth! a young one bursting! where is the weeping mouth?
And where the mothers milk? instead those ever-hissing jaws
And parched lips drop with fresh gore; now roll thou in the clouds
Thy mother lays her length outstretch'd upon the shore beneath.
Sound! sound! my loud war-trumpets & alarm my thirteen Angels!
Loud howls the eternal Wolf: the eternal Lion lashes his tail!

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although the plate contains considerable text, the pictorial image is treated as a full-plate design. Below the text, a nude, muscular, youthful male rises among flames. His hair is curly and snake-like; his mouth is open. He faces forward, but looks slightly to the left. Both legs are bent at the knee, with his left leg drawn up toward his chest. His lower right leg may be bent under his prominent left foot but is obscured by the flames. This posture suggests that he is floating or kneeling in the flames. The figure is very probably Orc, the spirit of revolution. His arms are raised horizontally, with his hands resting on the flames. The visible fingers of both hands are spread apart; both hands are poised as though the man was calling forth the flames that surround him. The flames (of hell?) extend up both margins to the top of the plate and appear in the spaces between the text, particularly between lines 4 and 5. The design offers a contrasting parallel to the design on plate 12.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude, muscular, youthful male rises among flames. His hair is curly and snake-like; his mouth is open. He faces forward, but looks slightly to the left. His arms are raised horizontally, with his hands resting on the flames. The visible fingers of both hands are spread apart; both hands are poised as though the man was calling forth the flames that emanate from below.
The figure is surrounded by flames (of hell?) that climb to the top of the plate along both margins and appear between lines 5 and 6 of the text and between lines 11 and 12 on the right.

Extensions of letters at the beginning of lines 4 and 11 form vine-like tendrils. The extension of the "y" in the first word of line 11 forms a loop. A loopy vine extends from the second letter of "those" (line 6); the extensions of the first letter of "Golden" (line 8) are also vine-like.

lg.l: Thus wept the Angel voice & as he wept the terrible blasts
Of trumpets, blew a loud alarm across the Atlantic deep.
No trumpets answer; no reply of clarions or of fifes,
Silent the Colonies remain and refuse the loud alarm.
On those vast shady hills between America & Albions shore;
Now barr'd out by the Atlantic sea: call'd Atlantean hills;
Because from their bright summits you may pass to the Golden world.
An ancient palace, archetype of mighty Emperies.
Rears its immortal pinnacles, built in the forest of God
By Ariston the king of beauty for his stolen bride,
Here on their magic seats the thirteen Angels sat perturb'd.
For clouds from the Atlantic hover o'er the solemn roof.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although the plate contains a good deal of text, Blake treated the pictorial image as a full-plate design. Above, an old, bearded, and gowned man sits among clouds. His long hair cascades over his left shoulder. He faces forward, but looks slightly to the left. His arms are raised horizontally; his hands seem to be holding the clouds on which they rest, palms down. His right leg is drawn up toward his chest in a contracted posture; the right knee and foot are prominent. His left leg is not pictured. The lines below his right foot may be a fold of his garment, but possibly a sandal. This figure is very probably Urizen. At the bottom of the plate is a dark and stormy sea with waves. The text panel is shaped in such a way as to suggest a cloud between the upper and lower parts of the design, or possibly a break between clouds. The design, particularly the figure, offers a contrasting parallel to the design on plate 11.

component.illusobjdesc: An old, bearded, and gowned man sits among clouds. His long hair cascades over his left shoulder. He faces forward, but looks slightly to the left. His arms are raised horizontally; his hands seem to be holding the clouds on which they rest, palms down. The visible fingers on his hands are spread apart. His right leg is drawn up toward his chest in a contracted posture; the right knee and foot are prominent. His left leg is not pictured. The lines below his right foot may be a fold of his garment, but possibly a sandal. This is probably Urizen.
Below the text is a dark and stormy sea with waves.
Dense clouds form both the surface on which the figure sits and his background. The text panel is shaped like a cloud, or possibly a break between clouds.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Vine-like extensions spring from the first letter in line 2, the "O" of "Orc" (line 2), and the first letters in lines 10 and 13. All but the first include loops.

lg.l: The terror answerd: I am Orc, wreath'd round the accursed tree:
The times are ended; shadows pass the morning gins to break:
The fiery joy, that Urizen perverted to ten commands,
What night he led the starry hosts thro' the wide wilderness;
That stony law I stamp to dust: and scatter religion abroad
To the four winds as a torn book, & none shall gather the leaves;
But they shall rot on desart sands, & consume in bottomless deeps,
To make the desarts blossom, & the deeps shrink to their fountains,
And to renew the fiery joy, and burst the stony roof.
That pale religious letchery, seeking Virginity,
May find it in a harlot, and in coarse-clad honesty
The undefil'd tho' ravish'd in her cradle night and morn:
For every thing that lives is holy, life delights in life;
Because the soul of sweet delight can never be defil'd.
Fires inwrap the earthly globe, yet man is not consumd;
Amidst the lustful fires he walks: his feet become like brass,
His knees and thighs like silver, & his breast and head like gold.

objnote.p: Object 13 is in the second state of two, with one tail on the snake, lower left.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although the plate contains considerable text, the pictorial image is treated as a full page design. Given the presence of stars and a crescent moon, this is a night scene. The sky is filled with clouds and the text panel is also shaped like a cloud. High in the sky, but below the first three lines of text, a giant swan flies on extended wings to the right. A youthful nude male rides on his back. The figure's legs are spread apart and dangle on each side of the swan's back just in front of its wings. The youth's hair is blown to the left by the onward flight of the bird. The man looks back to the left, away from the direction of flight, and braces himself with his right arm. His left arm is raised horizontally and he holds in his left hand a rein attached to the swan's beak. This figure has sometimes been identified as Boston's Angel, although the reason for this may be nothing more than the fact that he is named in the text immediately above the figure. To the right of the swan are four much smaller birds, all flying on extended wings. The largest of these has a forked tail. Below, and to the left of the text panel, are eight(?) stars; the upper seven of these may be a constellation, the Pleiades. One more star appears in the sky below the text near the crescent moon. It might be the planet Venus. Also below the text, but still in the night sky, are two more flying birds. The earth appears only along the lower margin; a small plant grows from the lower right corner. Three nude children ride on the back of a snake. The front-most child, perhaps a girl with long hair, holds a pair of reins in her left hand that extends to the snake's open mouth. Its forked tongue is prominent and at least one horn extends back from its head. The second child, further to the left, appears to be a male with curly hair. He braces himself with his left arm, perhaps holding on to the snake with his left hand, and reaches back with his right arm to hold hands with the very young child or infant nearest the snake's tail. This child reaches up, perhaps with both hands, but faces to the right and may be looking down. The right-most child has her legs together; the others have their legs spread on each side of the snake (although we see only their right legs). The snake's body forms a loop left of the children and terminates in two more loops and a single tail (two were eliminated in this, the second state of the plate).

component.illusobjdesc: Most of the design consists of the sky filled with clouds. The text panel is also shaped as a cloud. Given the presence of stars and a crescent moon, this would appear to be a night scene.
A single rein extends from the swan's beak to the rider's left hand.
A pair of reins extends from the snake's mouth to the left hand of the child nearest the snake's head.

One star appears in the sky below the text near the crescent moon. It might be the planet Venus.
A crescent moon appears in the night sky.
A giant swan flies to the right on extended wings. The bird is ridden by a youthful male who holds a single rein attached to the partly-opened beak of the swan.
Four birds fly on extended wings right of the giant swan. Three birds are very small; the fourth is fairly large and has a prominent forked tail.
Two birds fly through the sky on extended wings between the last line of text and the snake below. The bird on the right has a forked tail.

A giant snake glides along the ground, probably moving to the right. Its mouth is open and its scales and forked tongue are clearly pictured. At least one horn extends horizontally back from its head. The snake's body on the left forms a single loop and, further to the left, a single tail in this, the second state of the plate.
A small plant with spiky leaves grows from the lower right corner.

A youthful and muscular nude male rides on the swan's back. The figure's legs are spread apart and they dangle on each side of the swan's back just in front of its wings. The youth's hair is blown to the left by the onward flight of the bird. The figure looks back to the left, away from the direction of flight, and braces himself with his right arm. His left arm is raised horizontally and he holds in his left hand a rein attached to the swan's beak. This figure has sometimes been identified as Boston's Angel, although the reason for this may be nothing more than the fact that he is named in the text immediately above the figure.

A nude child, perhaps female, rides on the back of the snake nearest his head. She holds in her raised left hand a pair of reins attached to the snake's mouth. Her legs are together; her right arm is either at her side or behind her back and braced on the snake's back. She looks to the right; her long hair trails to the left.

A nude child, probably a male with curly hair, rides on the back of the snake. His legs are spread apart. He braces himself with his left arm and may be holding onto the snake with his left hand. He reaches back with his right hand to hold the hand of the child or infant to the left.

A very young nude child or infant of uncertain gender rides on the snake's back nearest its tail. He or she faces to the right and raises his or her right arm to hold hands with the child further to the right.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Several motifs follow line 9. These are, from left to right, a stick figure with arms raised horizontally and striding to the left; a vine, perhaps with leaves, on which the figure walks; a vine with a loop, extending upward from the "d" of "commanded" in the line below; a mammal of some sort (a horse or fox?) with a bushy tail, running or leaping to the left; a vine extending from the "h" of "what" in the line below; and a series of swirls that may represent vines. Three birds fly above "the energies" (line 12); two fly above "and generosity" (line 13). Many letters bear vine-line extensions; those at the beginning of lines 2 and 14 contain loops, as does the vine extending above "& the" (line 14). The vine arching over "frowns" (line 7) may bear small leaves. There is a detached vine above "abstinence & wraps" (line 17).

component.illusobjdesc: At the end of line 9, a stick figure with arms raised horizontally strides to the left.
At the end of line 9, and right of the human figure, a mammal of some sort, perhaps a horse or fox with a bushy tail, runs or leaps to the left.

The motifs following line 9 include three vines, one between the man and the animal extending from the "d" of "commanded" in line 10, one extending from the "h" of "what" in line 10, and the largest above the last three words of line 10. All contain loops.
Three birds fly above "the energies" (line 12); two fly above "and generosity" (line 13).

Many letters bear vine-line extensions; those at the beginning of lines 2 and 14 contain loops, as does the vine extending above "& the" (line 14). The vine arching over "frowns" (line 7) may bear small leaves. There is a detached vine above "abstinence & wraps" (line 17).

lg.l: Fiery the Angels rose, & as they rose deep thunder roll'd
Around their shores; indignant burning with the fires of Orc
And Bostons Angel cried aloud as they flew thro' the dark
night,
He cried; Why trembles honesty and like a murderer,
Why seeks he refuge from the frowns of his immortal station,
Must the generous tremble & leave his joy, to the idle: to
the pestilence!
That mock him? who commanded this; what God! what Angel!
To keep the gen'rous from experience till the ungenerous
Are unrestraind performers of the energies of nature;
Till pity is become a trade, and generosity a science,
That men get rich by, & the sandy desart is giv'n to the strong
What God is he, writes laws of peace, & clothes him in a tempest
What pitying Angel lusts for tears, and fans himself with sighs
What crawling villain preaches abstinence & wraps himself
In fat of lambs? no more I follow, no more obedience pay.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although containing considerable text, the plate is treated as a full-page design. Lower left, an old man enters a tomb. The post and lintel doorway, very probably built of stones, makes the tomb look like the entrance to a mine shaft. The heavy wooden door is partly open, revealing within darkness. The old, bearded man wears a heavy gown; his prominent left foot can be seen under the hem. He faces, and is probably walking, to the left—into the tomb. He is bent over and leans on a crutch held in his left hand and propped beneath his left armpit. His hair appears to be blown by a wind from right to left, and hence towards the tomb entrance. To the right of the tomb is the trunk of a massive tree with a root extending along the ground to the right. The tree apparently continues behind the tomb and then grows above it, where we see more of the trunk and two or three branches with a few leaves. Behind and to the right of the lower trunk of the tree is a form that is probably another tree trunk. Further to the right below the text is a dark background with white lines suggesting clouds. In other copies, a landscape below the clouds shows hills or distant mountains, perhaps covered with trees.

component.illusobjdesc: An old, bearded man wearing a heavy gown walks to the left and into the entrance to a tomb. His prominent left foot can be seen under the hem of his garment. He is bent over and leans on a crutch held in his left hand and propped beneath his left armpit. His hair appears to be blown by a wind from right to left, and hence towards the tomb entrance.
Small shadows extend to the left from the old man's left foot and crutch.

The old man enters a tomb. The post and lintel doorway, very probably built of stones, makes the tomb look like the entrance to a mine shaft. The heavy wooden door, with a large hinge visible just above the figure's back, is partly open, revealing within darkness.
To the right of the large tree trunk next to the tomb is another form with bold hatching lines. This is probably another tree trunk.
The dark background on the lower right side of the plate suggests a stormy sky with heavy clouds.

To the right of the tomb is the trunk of a massive tree with a root extending along the ground to the right. The tree apparently continues behind the tomb and then grows above it, where we see more of the trunk and two or three branches with a few leaves.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Several vegetative forms decorate the text. The most prominent are the vine (or perhaps a worm?) descending from the first letter of the first line; two vines in line 8; and a vine or worm extending from the last letter of "its" in line 13, very close to the right margin of the plate. The extension of the final letter of "cried" (line 2) forms a loop; other vegetative forms appear above "rending" (line 2), above the second ampersand in line 10, as an extension of the first letter in line 11, and above "furnace" in line 16.

Two vines extend horizontally in line 8. The vine on the right may bear leaves.
